How was this number chosen, and do you think there would be any need for adjustment in certain conditions that we might need to document in a KB article?

This number was chosen by guess. we can easily set it up to 100, or 1000.

However, the lower, the better, since the queue takes up memory (and when removing metrics from the queue, queue maintenance is not cost free either).

and read the "usual" number of metrics to be pushed.

cmd/secret/get/get_target_kubeconfig.go.message: This should be more generic, like cluster-kubeconfig.

Just something to consider, maybe as a next step, maybe now. Namespace could come from manifests instead, and from command line we supply the phase name (and have default) in which we keep cluster object, then we find that cluster object, and extract namespace from it.

If you mean to provide phase name for this new command to retrieve kubeconfig from secret then I think this is not logically connected and it's better to provide namespace. Furthermore, anyway it's an additional parameter like namespace. Besides that extraction of the namespace from the manifest based on phase name looks like extra complexity added for this particular CLI. One more thing here is that the manifest can be written without namespace in it. This will lead to extra logic to provide default namespace if there is no field in the manifest. Sure, it's not a big deal to implement but is it worth it? What do we achieve by that? If we have a strong explanation for that then it can be implemented in a separate PS.

I can envision that we are going to use this by some other higher level tool like jenkins, zuul or any other CD tool, in such case, what should be a source of truth for the namespace here? I do agree that this can be a first step in the overall implementation of the feature. But it will not cover what we want, so i would suggest leaving "TODO" comments about this in code, namespace, as well as actually name should should be possible to be derived from document set. And yes, i agree that it adds complexity, that is why we are building this code, so that deployment complexity hidden in it, rather than put on Deployment Engineer's shoulders. I can imagine that there will be 30 clusters managed by single airshipctl instance, keeping track of cluster names and namespaces would be a mess, that is why we have a context associated with each document set, which in turn holds all this information, and this information is the source of truth.

Also, please note, that this way of getting the secret will be needed as well as logic of getting it from manifests. So I am not saying, that this is the wrong way, I am saying, that we need both ways.

testutil/utilities.go.message: Why cmd output testing requires message initialization? We don't initialize log module here for example.

pkg/config/config.go.message: I would say that reconcileConfig and other reconcile* methods are responsible for this not LoadConfig.

Unfortunately, parsing kube config file is a responsibility of external method in clientcmd that we use. So, when there is a typo in entry names or when we have missed entries we have just empty map from external method as a returned value and can't work without data. I checked what we can do in case like this and the only way I see for now is to throw appropriate errors when there is no enough data for reconciliation.

I don't think it's valid behavior when you are calling validation checks within LoadConfig function. Two reasons why:
1. You are performing only kubeconfig validation but not the entire config, that's weird at least.
2. The actual logic of LoadConfig is to load config, not to verify. It should load config and create Config object, and the only cases when LoadConfig fails - missing files or unable to read them as YAML. Also, validation checks could be different depending on subcommand action. That's why EnsureComplete calls are performing on subcommand level.

I'm introducing new logic here on code review. The bug was filed because of lost config in some cases. So, this is a fix for the bug. Answering question about kubeconfig: because it's under external control and we can't handle loading kubeconfig(see k8s clientcmd API for details). That's a root cause for the bug. The case when we have missing parts and/or typos in airconfig is not a root cause for this bug.
The new logic is to load config and verify critical parts to prevent config parts missing(see https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/issues/176).

Who defined this "new" logic? I don't see any proposals and approvals from core reviewers for this logic here [1] and anywhere else.
There is still unanswered question - why is only kubeconfig checked here? The regular config could also have missing parts and typos. 

[1] https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/issues/176

What's the purpose to split config and kubeconfig validation? You are throwing the same error (ErrMissingConfig) as in EnsureConfigComplete function and, in fact, you are verifying part of config object (because kubeConfig is a field of Config struct).

When we load config we only need to make sure that kubeConfig structure is fine because we need it for reconciliation and we don't control loading from the file(see comment above). If it has broken YAML structure/typos or missed parts we will see the bug from the description.
The type of error is the same but messages are different. This check is only for fields that cause a bug in the description. Other fields are optional.
So why wouldn't you perform config and kubeconfig validation in the same function?

pkg/config/config_test.go.message:
I don't see any asserts here.
Why don't you follow the approach of EnsureComplete test? You can load the config, then on the fly change parameters you need and verify expected behavior.
'requre' calls are enough in the InitBadConfig to test this case

I would avoid that, otherwise at some point we could get a bunch of pointless functions like InitBadConfig, InitGoodConfig, InitAverageConfig InitMissingFieldsConfig, whatever, which implements the same functionality. Look at your code - it's 99.9% the same as InitConfig function, you just using testBadKubeConfigYAML variable to write data to kubeconfig file. Make it configurable at least, we should reuse the code, not to generate the same one just for stats.

bootstrap_capz/config/aks_cluster.go.message: Why don't you use Azure SDK for this? Any limitations?

During the design call of Oct 15, there was a comment indicating that community is moving away from Go plugins and opting for CLI using Go exec.Command() approach.

Moreover, as the container application is isolated (a.k.a., black box) from the airshipctl command, how the container manages the deployment of a cluster was not considered relevant.
The initial request was for refactor the code and Go was chosen. This approach allowed to reuse az CLI code that had already been tested and validated.

bootstrap_capz/config/azure_cluster.go.message: I disagree with such an approach. Please, refactor your solution without running the shell script in the Go app. Run all steps in the shell or run all steps in the Go app. There is no need to combine.
I propose to refactor it after the merge.

I think using both Go and Bash inside the container may make sense, since each is the best tool for a job (e.g. driving the aks CLI).  However as Stas points out, it's a little weird to have a go app driving a shell script instead of the other way around.  Would it be possible to use a shell script entrypoint to invoke Bash for some tasks, and Go for other other tasks?

Ok, if you decided to stick with Go, please, do all steps in Go.

JFYI: you can parse YAML/JSON in bash scripts by utilizing jq/yq
Are there any complications of using bash for all operations(extract values, set env vars, run something with these vars)?

The Go code is used to parse the configuration file (yaml or json) and the extracted values from this config file are used to set environment variables for the create/delete cluster shell script. I used the approach of having the Go code driving/orchestrating, kind of, DevOps operations and in this case invoking a shell script, but in theory it could also be any bash commands.

It is the parsing of a YAML/JSON configuration file that prompt me to opt for Go, with the assumption that it would not be a trivial task using bash. Once, started the Go code, it made sense to follow that path. Not saying that it couldn't be done in a different way/style.

I see code duplication between this file and https://review.opendev.org/#/c/752298/8/bootstrap_capg/config/gcp_cluster.go

I disagree with such an approach and would like to suggest to create a universal wrapper and just provide cloud provider-specific information for this wrapper.

It can be done in a separate commit and may look like a Go package.
Anyway, all these scripts and approaches should be refactored.
Each bootstrap container is supposed to be isolated from each other. It just happen that we are using the similar code.
I understand that we use it in different containers. This can be done by sharing Golang module during compilation.

The point I am trying to make is that the execute() function in one Container code may evolve without the need to know if it is going to affect another container code.

This isolation from each provider's container will allow each provider to evolve as it pleases without caring about maintaining backward compatibility with other providers' container when changing this code.

I would not disagree with your argument if it was in the same binary but this is not the case here.

I'm not talking about execution, it's all about compilation. This is one repo to produce different binaries and part of the code in these binaries is the same. For such cases in programming, we use libraries and modules.

So, you developed a wrapper for public cloud providers. This definitely can be modularized.

zuul.d/project-templates.yaml.message: I don't think we should pin this to the master branch. This template will be applied to master today then wallaby in ~6 months. Would be better to have zuul infer the branch based on the runtime context.
I think what this currently does is it runs the non-voting test on master, which is wallaby now, but when stable/wallaby gets cut it will no longer run.

I could see it either way. It really is only interesting while master is wallaby, because presumably we will be testing py39 or hopefully py10 in X. On the other hand, if a repo is configured to run wallaby tests, it shouldn't matter if it is on the master branch or not (like stable/wallaby).

I think I prefer it just being tied to the template, not the branch. If we want to keep non-voting jobs around in stable branches to help ensure there are no regressions, then we can. If we decide at some point that it is just a waste of gate resources to run these jobs on a stable branch, then we can just remove this non-voting job from the template.

Since we get a new vim client each loop, we cannot get the auth failure from an expired token.  this block will be removed
Should this be treated as a failure case?
Maybe.  The way I would normally see this happening is if someone manually created it in the vim.  Since we now delete when strategy is deleted,  having this fail here is a way to recover as well.
In what use case this is possible after this commit?

If the subcloud goes offline AFTER orchestration completes, it will not fail the orchestration. The delete will then delete the strategy without deleting the strategy in that subcloud. That will lead to this case being hit if a new strategy is created (and the subcloud is online again).

This links to my other review comment related to deleting the VIM strategi(es) when the orchestration completes but you already answered that so this code to handle the described corner case makes sense. The existing vim strategy that is not in failed/aborted state then should be deleted and and a new one created for this round as opposed to be re-used.
This could happen in some error cases. For example, if the subcloud went offline after the strategy was applied, but before it was deleted.

If the subcloud went offline, the orchestration would fail for that subcloud. To resume when the subcloud is online again, a new orchestration strategy will have to be created. This requires deleting the previous orchestration strategy during which the VIM strategies are deleted.

This info log is in VIM strategy creation code hence the ask.

Al - I think Tee makes a good point. If we do get in this state where we have a failed strategy in the subcloud, it would make sense to delete it here if we detect it. This would basically be the code you had, but please change the state check to match the check in delete_subcloud_strategy (i.e. delete it if it is not building, applying or aborting).

May want to update the message. It's currently in creating strategy so mentioning of delete without any context can be confusing.

Perhaps something along the line
"Failed to create a VIM strategy for <region-name>. There already is an existing strategy in <state-name> state."
warn_log already includes the region and the state, and the code that catches the exception logs those as well.  I will change the wording around to indicate the problem is a previous vim strategy

I may not have the full context as I don't see why this code had to be removed. VIM fw update strategy should be removed at the end of a successful orchestration as opposed to part of an orchestration strategy delete unless the orchestration strategy failed.

The original design decision when patch orchestration was implemented was to only delete the subcloud strategy when the overall strategy was deleted. This allows us to (for example) collect timing information from each subcloud after the strategy is applied. I want all types of orchestration to be consistent so I asked Al to make this change.
